instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesnâ€™t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Without Picture, Backlight and Sound
threads.message:
MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Without Picture, Backlight and Sound
Hello friends, first of all, I hope you have a good day.

I need help with a MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that stays at a consumption of 0.444A to 0.464A, the fan spins at maximum speed I don't know much about how to repair macbook I'm new but what I have measured the main lines are present, <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is present.
I checked the entire board and it has no sulfate water damage etc. only
There seems to be damage to some coils:
L1290
L1275
L1295
L1270

and in the TestPoint
<SIGNAL>CPU_THRMTRIP_3V3</SIGNAL>

Also the ssd hard drive gets very hot.

I hope you can help me

This text was translated with google translator, since my English is somewhat bad.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Without Picture, Backlight and Sound
threads.message:
Do you have voltage at L7310/20?
Also check <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, if present.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Without Picture, Backlight and Sound
threads.message:
yes, 1.8V on both L7310/20

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3volt --> ohms 150k --> Diode 0.538V

<CHIP>U2071</CHIP> looks a bit weird

threads.message: Check <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_BUF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Without Picture, Backlight and Sound
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_BUF_L</SIGNAL>.
Diode: 0.632v
ohms: 100k
voltage: 3.32v

Try known good BIOS.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Without Picture, Backlight and Sound
threads.message:
I suppose you don't have Medusa programmer, or any other tool to do this onboard.
Then you need to remove the SPI chip (<CHIP>U6100</CHIP>) and flash it using an USB programmer; CH341, TL866, EZP2019, RT809, etc.

Test it on both ports.

threads.message: Perfecto amigo, acabo de probar en ambos puertos y no prende el led de mi USB, al conectarlo a mi computadora de uso si enciende el led, pero al conectarlo al MacBook que estamos diagnosticando no enciende el led, en ninguno de los dos puertos

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Without Picture, Backlight and Sound
threads.message:
Revisa que tengas todas las tensiones de la pag 11.

Tambien comprueba todos los resistores SPI Bus Series Termination y sus pistas (pag 46).
Limpia J6100, si notas corrosion.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Without Picture, Backlight and Sound
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SPI_ALT_CLK</SIGNAL> = 3.2v al inicio pero baja a 0v
<SIGNAL>SPI_ALT_IO0_MOSI</SIGNAL> = 3.2 al inicio pero  0v
 las otras lineas si mantienen 3.2v  = <SIGNAL>SPI_ALT_IO1_MISO</SIGNAL>,  <SIGNAL>SPI_ALT_IO2_WP_L</SIGNAL>,  <SIGNAL>SPI_ALT_IO3_HOLD_L</SIGNAL>,  <SIGNAL>SPI_ALT_CS_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Without Picture, Backlight and Sound
threads.message:
revise todas las lineas de lapagina 11 y a mi parecer estan todas, ahorita mismo compruebo las lineas del j6100
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0SW_AUDIO_HDA</SIGNAL> = 1.5v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL> = 1.046
PP1V05_S0_PCH_VCCACLKPLL_R -- L1270 = 1.04 en ambos lados 
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_PCH_VCC_ICC_R</SIGNAL> -- L1275 = 1.04 en ambos lados
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_PCH_VCCAPLL_OPI</SIGNAL> = 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL> -- L1290 = 1.04v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL> -- L1295 = 1.04v

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Without Picture, Backlight and Sound
threads.message:
No me has entendido :(.
Los resistores mencionados son de 15, 25 y 43 ohmios; esperemos que ninguno este abierto.
Despues, debes revisar todas las pistas entre esos resistores y <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> ; que no son pocas!
O sea que debes revisar la continuidad de un resistor a otro, segun el esquema.

Por cierto, revisa tambien los pads y pistas de <CHIP>U6101</CHIP>.
